study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze changes in psychopathology in morbidly obese bariatric surgery candidates after cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and assess differences based on binge eating disorder (BED) status and obesity grade.
results_summary: CBT significantly improved psychological comorbidity in bariatric surgery candidates, eliminating baseline differences in self-esteem, depression, and eating disorders between BED and non-BED patients. Weight loss >10% was achieved in 61% of patients at 1 year post-CBT, with no differences between groups.
population_specificity: 110 morbidly obese bariatric surgery candidates (77 females; aged 41 ± 9 years; BMI 49.1 ± 9.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the overall effects of bariatric surgery compared with non-surgical treatment for obesity, focusing on weight loss, cardiovascular risk factors, quality of life, and adverse events.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in greater weight loss, higher remission rates of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome, improved quality of life, and reduced medicine use compared to non-surgical treatment. Adverse events included iron deficiency anemia (15%) and reoperations (8%), with no reported cardiovascular events or deaths.
population_specificity: Individuals with a body mass index ≥ 30.
study_duration: Follow-up ≥ 6 months (results limited to two years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and mini-gastric bypass (MGB) on weight loss and glycemic control in obese patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that MGB showed a trend toward higher diabetes remission rates compared to SG, with high hemoglobin A1c being a negative predictor of remission. However, definitive conclusions were limited due to the study's small sample size and lack of long-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes referred to the University of Naples "Federico II" from 2009 to 2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus diet and exercise on the survival and transplant access of morbidly obese patients with end-stage renal disease awaiting renal transplant.
results_summary: RYGB improved survival and increased transplant frequency compared to diet and exercise, with patients gaining significantly more years of life (5.4 years vs. 1.5-2.8 years for diet/exercise). The benefit was consistent across different BMI eligibility thresholds (35 kg/m² and 40 kg/m²).
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with end-stage renal disease awaiting renal transplant.
study_duration: Not specified (comparison included 1 and 2 years of diet/exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update clinical guidelines on metabolic and bariatric surgery, focusing on evidence related to diabetes effects and changes in patient eligibility criteria.
results_summary: The study highlighted advancements in metabolic surgery and revised guidelines to reflect current knowledge, expertise, and evidence-based data, particularly regarding its effects on diabetes and updated patient eligibility.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and obesity-associated diseases, particularly those with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a long-term treatment for obesity and its related comorbidities, particularly focusing on its metabolic benefits beyond weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is highly effective for long-term weight loss and significantly improves or resolves obesity-related comorbidities, such as type 2 diabetes, by altering hormonal secretion and glucose metabolism. It also highlights the evolving role of metabolic surgery in multidisciplinary diabetes management.
population_specificity: Patients with higher degrees of obesity and related metabolic disorders, particularly type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: To determine the impact of biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD-DS) surgery on cardiovascular risk profile and predicted cardiovascular risk in severely obese patients.
results_summary: BPD-DS surgery led to significant weight loss, improved metabolic markers (HbA1C, HOMA-IR, lipoprotein levels, blood pressure), and reduced 10-year CHD predicted risk by 43% in women and 33% in men. Post-surgery, a higher proportion of patients shifted to low short-term/low lifetime predicted risk categories.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients (n = 73 surgical group, n = 33 control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effect of bariatric surgery on echocardiographic indices of biventricular function and clarify expected echocardiographic changes post-surgery.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery may help reverse some cardiovascular sequelae of obesity, but notes that prior studies used nonhomogeneous groups, indicating variability in findings. The review seeks to consolidate these findings for better understanding.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly those at risk of diastolic and systolic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the importance of BMI as a mortality predictor, identify other mortality predictors, and develop a mortality prediction rule for individuals eligible for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that a simple 4-variable prediction rule (age, sex, smoking, and diabetes mellitus) effectively estimated 10-year all-cause mortality in obese individuals eligible for bariatric surgery, while BMI was not a significant predictor. Mortality rates varied across four risk tiers, ranging from 0.2% to 5.2%.
population_specificity: 15,394 patients aged 18 to 65 years with BMI ≥35.0 alone or 30.0-34.9 with an obesity-related comorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional brain changes associated with behavioral weight loss interventions versus bariatric surgery in obese individuals.
results_summary: Behavioral dieters showed increased activation in brain regions linked to food valuation, while bariatric patients exhibited increased activation in areas associated with higher-level perception. The method of weight loss influenced distinct changes in brain function.
population_specificity: Obese participants (15 for bariatric surgery, 16 for behavioral diet intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of obesity among hospitalized adults and evaluate the extent to which eligible obese patients were referred for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found a significant burden of obesity (22% of hospitalized patients), with low rates of dietetic review (21%) and bariatric surgery referral (10%) among eligible patients. It highlights missed opportunities for obesity intervention during hospital admissions.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adults in the UK, with a focus on orthopaedic patients and intensive care unit admissions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current surgical and endoscopic options for weight loss in morbidly obese patients, including their efficacy and complications.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is effective for obesity and its comorbidities, with new techniques maximizing weight loss and metabolic outcomes while minimizing complications. Endoscopic options also play a role in treating obesity and managing surgical complications.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients, with potential applicability to mildly obese individuals with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose clinical indications for body composition assessment, including in bariatric surgery patients, and discuss contraindications to such testing.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding bariatric surgery's effects but mentions it as one of the scenarios examined for body composition assessment indications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general clinical patients, including bariatric surgery candidates)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pathophysiology of vitamin B12 deficiency in bariatric surgery patients and evaluate the effectiveness of various vitamin B12 formulations for prevention and management.
results_summary: Intramuscular vitamin B12 remains the gold standard for deficiency treatment, especially in symptomatic patients. High-dose oral cyanocobalamin may be considered for asymptomatic RYGB patients with adherence concerns, while restrictive procedures may require lower-dose daily supplementation. Nasal and sublingual routes lack sufficient efficacy data.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (e.g., Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, gastric banding, sleeve gastrectomy).
effective_dosage: High-dose oral cyanocobalamin (specific amount not stated), lower-dose daily vitamin B12 (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update clinical guidelines on metabolic and bariatric surgery, focusing on its effects on diabetes and revising patient eligibility criteria.
results_summary: The study highlighted significant advancements in metabolic and bariatric surgery over the past decade, emphasizing its impact on diabetes and updating recommendations for patient selection. The expert panel consolidated evidence to reflect current knowledge and best practices.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and obesity-associated diseases, particularly those with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on pregnancy outcomes, including maternal and fetal risks and benefits.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is associated with meaningful and sustained weight loss, reduced rates of pre-eclampsia and gestational diabetes, but increased rates of stillbirth and small-for-gestational-age babies, highlighting the importance of micronutrient screening and supplementation.
population_specificity: Women, particularly younger age groups, who underwent bariatric surgery and later became pregnant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify patient perceptions and clinical factors influencing the choice between Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding.
results_summary: Older patients, those with higher quality of life scores, and uncontrolled eating were more likely to choose gastric banding, while patients with type 2 diabetes, those desiring greater weight loss, and those willing to assume higher mortality risk were less likely to choose banding. Other clinical factors became insignificant after adjustment for patient preferences and behaviors.
population_specificity: Patients seeking bariatric surgery at two academic centers in Boston.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the additional health care utilization, cost, and mortality resulting from surgical site infections (SSIs) after bariatric surgery compared to patients without SSIs.
results_summary: Patients with SSIs after bariatric surgery had longer hospital stays, higher 30-day readmission rates, and significantly higher total medical costs compared to matched cohorts without SSIs. Mortality differences were not significant for the bariatric surgery cohort.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery with and without surgical site infections (SSIs).
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed up to one year postdischarge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in medication usage after silastic ring laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (SR-LRYGB) versus laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) over 5 years.
results_summary: Both SR-LRYGB and LSG reduced the need for diabetic and cardiovascular medications but increased requirements for nutritional supplementation, analgesia, and psychiatric medications. SR-LRYGB showed a greater reduction in oral anti-diabetic prescriptions compared to LSG, but no other differences in medication usage were found.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (52 in each group after exclusions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the correct management of pregnancy following bariatric surgery, focusing on preconception counseling, nutrition assessment, and folic acid supplementation.
results_summary: The study found a twofold increase in birth defect risks for women who underwent bariatric surgery before pregnancy, particularly before folic acid fortification, but also noted a reduced risk of major birth defects in infants born to mothers with bariatric surgery, potentially linked to improved glucose metabolism. It also outlined strategies for managing gestational diabetes and other pregnancy-related complications in this population.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence and guidance on nutrition during pregnancy after weight loss surgery, focusing on its safety, efficacy, and impact on maternal and fetal outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves obstetric outcomes compared to conservative management in severely obese women but increases risks of maternal nutritional deficiencies and small-for-gestational-age infants, especially if pregnancy occurs during rapid weight loss. Lifelong micronutrient supplementation and delayed pregnancy until weight stabilization are recommended.
population_specificity: Women with severe obesity, particularly those who become pregnant after weight loss surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein intake higher than the recommended value improves body composition changes (e.g., weight, fat mass, fat-free mass) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Higher protein intake led to greater weight loss (4.95 kg) and fat mass loss (7.64 kg) but had no significant effects on BMI, fat-free mass, percent fat mass, or total weight loss, except in laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy patients, where it reduced fat-free mass loss.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maternal diet, micronutrient supplementation, and gestational weight gain after bariatric surgery and their impact on maternal micronutrient deficiency, offspring growth, and perinatal outcomes.
results_summary: Many women did not achieve healthy gestational weight gain, but no consistent link with adverse outcomes was reported. The studies had methodological limitations, impacting the reliability of findings.
population_specificity: Pregnant women who had undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of time-in-range (TIR) as a novel metric for assessing blood glucose fluctuations and predicting the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in managing type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that TIR is a promising indicator for evaluating short-term blood glucose fluctuations and assessing the effectiveness of bariatric surgery, complementing traditional HbA1c measurements. TIR provides a more accurate reflection of glucose levels and pancreatic islet function, unaffected by caloric restriction.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutritional status and outcomes of vegetarian versus omnivorous patients before and after bariatric surgery to determine if vegetarianism increases the risk of nutritional deficiencies post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in nutritional deficiencies or weight loss between vegetarians and omnivores after bariatric surgery, with both groups showing comparable biological profiles and weight loss outcomes when taking standard vitamin supplementation.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients, including 7 vegetarians (4 lacto-ovo-vegetarians, 2 lacto-vegetarians, 1 lacto-ovo-pesco-vegetarian) and matched omnivores.
effective_dosage: Standard vitamin supplementation (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 4-week preoperative omega-3 PUFA supplementation could reduce liver left lateral section (LLLS) volume in morbidly obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in LLLS volume, total liver volume, liver steatosis, or operative time with omega-3 PUFA supplementation compared to placebo. The intervention was ineffective in achieving its primary outcome.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals with metabolic syndrome undergoing bariatric surgery at 3 French bariatric centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between bariatric surgery and determinants of periconception maternal health, including endocrine changes, fertility, vitamin status, menstrual cycles, miscarriages, and congenital malformations.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery normalized hormonal axes, restored menstrual cycle regularity, and increased fertility without short-term risks for miscarriages or congenital malformations, though vitamin deficiencies were more common post-surgery. A meta-analysis confirmed reduced infertility and menstrual irregularities but found no significant difference in miscarriage or malformation rates.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the nutritional needs and risks for pregnant women who have undergone bariatric surgery, providing guidelines for caregivers.
results_summary: The study highlights the high risk of nutritional deficiencies in pregnant women post-bariatric surgery, emphasizing the need for proper supplementation and close follow-up to mitigate risks for both mother and child.
population_specificity: Pregnant women who have undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of bariatric surgery on gut microbiota composition and functionality, and its potential influence on host metabolism and surgical outcomes.
results_summary: The review highlights that bariatric surgery alters gut microbiota, but conclusive assertions are limited. New research focuses on microbiota functionality and metabolites, with potential for personalized medicine, though manipulation strategies like probiotics remain understudied.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies, primarily Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether general folate supplementation recommendations are adequate for bariatric surgery patients, particularly during pregnancy, and to assess the risks of folate deficiency and over-supplementation.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery can induce micronutrient deficiencies, particularly folate, which may increase the risk of congenital anomalies in pregnancies. It questions the adequacy of standard folate recommendations for bariatric patients and discusses the risks of both deficiency and over-supplementation.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients, with a focus on pregnant individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to categorize guidelines related to nutrition, physical activity, and supplement prescription before and after bariatric surgery to improve surgical outcomes.
results_summary: The study reviewed existing guidelines and emphasized the importance of lifestyle modifications, such as healthy nutrition and physical activity, to enhance bariatric surgery results. It did not provide new efficacy data but synthesized recommendations for medical teams.
population_specificity: Not specified (general bariatric surgery patients)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the knowledge and practices of bariatric surgery professionals worldwide regarding the nutritional aspects of the ERAS protocol, including preoperative fasting, carbohydrate loading, and early postoperative nutrition.
results_summary: The study found that while most professionals were aware of the ERAS protocol, implementation varied significantly across continents, with no uniformity in preoperative fasting, immediate postoperative diet, or early protein supplementation practices. ERAS principles were partially and insufficiently implemented globally despite widespread professional knowledge.
population_specificity: Bariatric and metabolic surgery professionals (surgeons, nutritionists, anesthesiologists) from five continents (Africa, America, Asia, Europe, Oceania).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the perioperative anesthetic management and safety of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that inhalational anesthesia with remifentanil and rocuronium-sugammadex was safe, with minimal complications (3.2% bronchospasm, 1.1% bradycardia). Conventional intubation techniques were effective for most patients, but preparations for difficult intubation were recommended.
population_specificity: 95 patients (mean age 37.4±12.1 years, mean BMI 46 kg/m²) undergoing LSG at a Turkish university hospital.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose calculations based on lean/ideal body weight).
study_duration: Retrospective review of procedures performed between January 2012 and December 2017.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and critique evidence for vitamin A, B1, C, or E deficiencies associated with bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The review found that all included studies were of low quality (level IV grade) and neutral or negative in quality, with no focus on micronutrient supplementation or inflammatory markers for validating serum vitamin levels. Future research is needed to investigate deficiency risks with attention to confounders.
population_specificity: Not specified (general bariatric surgery patients)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in obese individuals and those undergoing bariatric surgery, focusing on achieving optimal 25(OH)D concentrations and assessing its impact on bone health and metabolic parameters.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D doses ≥2000 IU/d were needed to reach 25(OH)D concentrations of 30 ng/ml post-bariatric surgery, with inconsistent effects on bone mineral density and no clear benefit on weight loss or cardio-metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, those undergoing medical weight loss, and post-bariatric surgery patients.
study_duration: At least 3 months (specific duration varied by trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate vitamin D deficiency and body composition in women after bariatric surgery and relate BMI variation post-surgery to 25(OH)D concentrations.
results_summary: Women who underwent bariatric surgery (RYGB) had higher BMI and vitamin D deficiency, along with hyperparathyroidism, compared to controls. Vitamin D concentrations negatively correlated with BMI variation post-surgery, but no association was found between body composition variables and 25(OH)D levels.
population_specificity: 49 obese adult women who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).

study_goal: To evaluate changes in the ocular surface in obese patients before and after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: No significant differences were found in ocular surface tests between pre- and postoperative groups, and no symptoms of xerophthalmia developed. A high rate of noncompliance with nutritional supplementation was observed.
population_specificity: 89 obese patients (91% women), including preoperative, 0-12 months postoperative, and >12 months postoperative groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate folate status in women of childbearing age affected by obesity and its implications for supplementation before conception.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results on folate status in non-pregnant women with obesity, noting reduced plasma folate levels and increased erythrocyte folate uptake, suggesting a need for personalized supplementation.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age affected by obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the bone metabolism consequences of vitamin D deficiency after bariatric surgery and evaluate the variability of 25(OH)D response to supplementation in postmenopausal obese women.
results_summary: The study highlights that vitamin D deficiency is common in obese individuals and can worsen after bariatric surgery, increasing the risk of metabolic bone disease and fractures. It emphasizes the importance of recognizing and treating vitamin D deficiency preoperatively to avoid complications.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of vitamin D status and supplementation in surgery-induced weight loss and its effects on post-surgery complications.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency and hyperparathyroidism were detected in post-surgery patients, and vitamin D supplementation improved these complications. However, vitamin D supplementation did not significantly increase weight loss but may affect body fat loss.
population_specificity: Post-bariatric surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of sleeve gastrectomy on vitamin D status and the effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in bariatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that initial vitamin D supplementation of at least 3000 IU/day post-operatively is recommended, with one trial confirming its effectiveness in improving vitamin D status. However, ongoing monitoring is necessary as recommended levels are often not reached.
population_specificity: Bariatric patients (before and after sleeve gastrectomy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current management options for obesity and evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on cardiovascular risk factors and outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to provide sustained BMI reduction and marked improvements in cardiovascular risk factors, including hypertension, dyslipidaemia, inflammation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, leading to reduced risks of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death. However, potential risks include surgical complications, nutritional deficiencies, and the need for lifelong nutritional supplementation.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity, particularly those with cardiovascular comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to detail the role of pharmacists in optimizing long-term pharmacotherapy for bariatric surgery patients and highlight the pharmacotherapy challenges in this population.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improves many chronic diseases but requires close monitoring due to pharmacokinetic changes and potential nutritional deficiencies. Pharmacists play a key role in managing medication dosage forms and disease states affected by the surgery.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients, particularly those undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, adjustable gastric banding, or sleeve gastrectomy.
interactions: Decreased absorption of some medications due to altered gastrointestinal tract anatomy and potentially increased concentrations of some medications due to decreased volume of distribution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize surgical indications, techniques, peri-operative management, outcomes, complications, patient satisfaction, and quality of life impact of circumferential contouring procedures for the lower trunk after massive weight loss.
results_summary: The review found that belt lipectomy and lower bodylift were the primary techniques used, with belt lipectomy better correcting hip back rolls and lower bodylift more effective for buttock and lateral thigh ptosis. Complications like wound dehiscence were reported, but patient satisfaction and quality of life scores were high across studies.
population_specificity: Patients with massive weight loss undergoing circumferential contouring of the lower trunk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postoperative protein supplementation improves weight reduction, body composition, and protein status in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Protein supplementation increased protein intake and improved body composition by enhancing fat mass loss and reducing lean body mass loss, though overall weight loss was similar between groups. Blood proteins and grip force showed no differences between groups.
population_specificity: Twenty obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Daily protein supplement (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review 25-hydroxyvitamin D status before and after bariatric surgery, assess the dose response of vitamin D supplementation, and evaluate the effect of surgical procedures on post-supplementation 25(OH)D levels.
results_summary: The study found that hypovitaminosis D persists in obese patients post-bariatric surgery despite supplementation, with mean 25(OH)D levels remaining below 30ng/ml. Higher supplementation doses (1100-7100IU/day) increased 25(OH)D levels by 9-13ng/ml, but results varied widely across studies.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare bone mineral density (BMD) changes at 1 year after three bariatric surgery procedures: LAGBP, LSG, and LRYGB.
results_summary: Bone loss at the hips occurred in all groups, with LRYGB causing significantly greater bone loss than LAGBP or LSG. Lumbar spine BMD remained unchanged in LSG and LRYGB but increased in LAGBP.
population_specificity: 120 patients (40 per group: 13 men and 27 premenopausal women per group) with a mean age of 30.0±6.5 years and BMI of 39.5±3.8 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which long-term weight loss is achievable through bariatric surgery, comparing it to dieting and weight regain patterns.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery offers insights into sustainable weight loss mechanisms, contrasting with the high failure rates of dieting, which often leads to weight regain and potential metabolic risks. It highlights the need to understand adipose tissue biology and exercise's role in weight management post-surgery.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses diverse populations attempting weight loss, but not specific to bariatric surgery patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the risk of nutrient deficiencies, particularly vitamin A, and potential ophthalmic complications following bariatric surgery, especially malabsorptive procedures.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery, particularly malabsorptive procedures, increases the risk of nutrient deficiencies, which can lead to symptomatic hypovitaminosis and ophthalmic complications if supplementation is inadequate. It covers key nutrients involved, possible eye-related complications, and management strategies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, especially malabsorptive procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize postoperative nutritional requirements and guidelines for optimizing weight loss and maintaining nutritional status after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of diet progression, nutrient intake, hydration, and multidisciplinary follow-up to manage postoperative care and prevent nutrient deficiencies. It emphasizes adherence to guidelines for effective weight loss and nutritional health.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of screening and vitamin K1 supplementation on serum levels in pregnant women with bariatric surgery and compare these levels with those in pregnant women without surgery.
results_summary: The study found that pregnant women with bariatric surgery had significantly lower vitamin K1 levels in the first trimester compared to controls, but supplementation improved levels by the third trimester. Prothrombin time remained normal, though higher in the surgical group, and most coagulation factors stayed within normal ranges.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a history of bariatric surgery (n=49) compared to pregnant women without surgery (n=27).
study_duration: First to third trimester of pregnancy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation in preventing postoperative vitamin D deficiency in patients who underwent bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly improved 1-year vitamin D depletion and 25-OHD levels, with a daily dosage of more than 800 IU being particularly effective. The benefits were more pronounced in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) compared to non-RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients who had undergone bariatric surgery (1,285 participants across 12 studies).
effective_dosage: More than 800 IU daily was effective; less than 800 IU daily was not.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of bariatric surgery on employment status in unemployed, severely obese patients from underserved populations.
results_summary: The study found that 24% of surgical patients acquired full-time employment postoperatively, compared to 9% of non-surgical patients, with a significant BMI reduction in the surgical group. Bariatric surgery may improve employment status in this cohort.
population_specificity: Unemployed, severely obese patients (primarily Hispanic and publicly insured) from an urban safety-net program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze worldwide Internet search trends for bariatric surgery-related terms from 2004-2012 and explore associations with media events, economic changes, and policy updates.
results_summary: Search volume for "bariatric surgery" declined 25% since 2004 but rose 5% from 2011-2012; "lap band" searches fell 30% over 5 years, while "gastric sleeve" increased 15%. Search spikes correlated with policy changes, insurance updates, and media coverage.
population_specificity: Worldwide Internet users searching bariatric surgery-related terms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on the pharmacotherapy approach to preventing and managing nutritional deficiencies in bariatric surgery patients since the 2008 guidelines.
results_summary: The study highlights that Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is associated with nutritional deficiencies due to various factors, including reduced caloric intake and poor food tolerability, and notes a lack of consistent guidance for healthcare practitioners.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients, specifically those undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and management strategies for pregnant women following bariatric surgery, focusing on multidisciplinary care and nutritional supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that pregnancy outcomes are worse after bariatric surgery, though obese women remain at risk for obesity-related complications. Neonatal outcomes post-surgery were comparable to the general population.
population_specificity: Pregnant women who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physiological mechanisms of nutrient and drug malabsorption after bariatric surgery and assess the resulting deficiencies and clinical implications.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery effectively achieves sustainable weight loss in morbidly obese patients but leads to significant nutrient deficiencies and altered drug absorption, necessitating screening and supplementation. The study highlights the need for further research on specific procedures and deficiencies.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in obese childbearing women following bariatric surgery and the need for better monitoring and supplementation strategies.
results_summary: The study warns that bariatric surgery can alter vitamin A status, potentially leading to VAD in obese childbearing women, despite its rarity in industrialized countries due to insufficient intake. It calls for targeted approaches to address this issue.
population_specificity: Obese childbearing women who have undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether implementing a clinical pathway (CP) for enhanced recovery in bariatric surgery improves perioperative quality of care.
results_summary: The CP group showed significant improvements in process quality indicators (e.g., earlier catheter removal, increased mobilization, better supplementation) and reduced hospital stay, but no significant differences in mortality, morbidity, re-operations, or re-admissions.
population_specificity: 129 consecutive patients undergoing bariatric surgery (65 in the CP group, 64 in the pre-CP group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evolution of bariatric surgery, focusing on current procedures in the U.S., and provide recommendations for diet, supplementation, and management of complications.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as the most effective treatment for morbid obesity, emphasizing multidisciplinary care to optimize outcomes and nutritional health. It reviews current procedures, dietary recommendations, and complication management.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and outcomes of various bariatric surgery procedures, including weight loss, comorbidity remission, and mortality risk.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in an average weight loss of 50% of excess body weight, with diabetes remission in 80% of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass patients. Comorbidities were greatly reduced, and health-related quality of life improved, though risks varied by procedure and patient factors.
population_specificity: Obese patients, particularly those with obesity-related comorbidities like diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of vitamin D supplementation in maintaining sufficient serum levels, particularly in vulnerable populations such as those who have undergone bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that higher doses of vitamin D (up to 2000 IU/day or more) are needed for vulnerable populations, including post-bariatric surgery patients, to maintain serum 25(OH)D levels above 30 ng/mL. It also highlighted the broader benefits of vitamin D on musculoskeletal and extraskeletal health.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, post-bariatric surgery patients, elderly, dark-skinned individuals, and those with gastrointestinal malabsorption syndromes.
effective_dosage: 600–2000 IU/day (up to 5000 IU/day reported as safe).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate perioperative strategies for detecting, preventing, and treating micronutrient deficiencies in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that micronutrient deficiencies are common in obese patients both before and after bariatric surgery, particularly with malabsorptive procedures. A systematic, team-based approach is recommended to reduce morbidity from delayed diagnosis and treatment.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish guidelines for diagnosing, managing, and preventing Wernicke encephalopathy (WE), particularly in relation to thiamine deficiency after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study recommends thiamine supplementation post-bariatric surgery for at least 6 months and highlights the importance of monitoring thiamine status to prevent WE. MRI and clinical signs are suggested for diagnosis, with thiamine administration being safe and effective.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery and other at-risk populations for thiamine deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the medium and long-term outcomes of biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD-DS) in terms of weight loss and safety.
results_summary: The study found that BPD-DS achieved sustainable significant weight loss (>71.9% excess weight loss) with >5 years of follow-up, though unsatisfactory results occurred in <20% of cases. Vitamin and micronutrient levels remained stable, but maintaining normal vitamin D levels was challenging despite supplementation.
population_specificity: 51 patients with a preoperative BMI of 47 ± 6.1 kg/m² who underwent BPD-DS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, metabolic effects, and clinical implications of bariatric surgery for severely obese patients with a BMI ≥35 kg/m².
results_summary: Bariatric surgery produces long-term weight loss, improves quality of life, reduces medication costs, and mitigates obesity-related comorbidities like type 2 diabetes and hypertension. However, it can lead to adverse effects such as micronutrient deficiencies and oxalate nephropathy, requiring dietary supplementation and medication adjustments.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients with a BMI ≥35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate thiamine status and supplementation in critically ill patients, including those who underwent bariatric surgery, to identify risks and benefits.
results_summary: The study found that thiamine deficiency is a concern in critically ill patients, including those with a history of bariatric surgery, and early supplementation may prevent severe neurological damage.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients, including those with a history of bariatric surgery, alcoholism, malnutrition, or long-term parenteral feeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risks and complications associated with bariatric surgery in pregnant women, focusing on nutritional deficiencies and other post-surgical complications.
results_summary: The study found that while bariatric surgery reduces obesity-related pregnancy complications, it introduces new risks such as internal hernias and nutritional deficiencies, particularly fat-soluble vitamins, requiring tailored supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a history of bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional risks and preventive measures associated with bariatric surgery, emphasizing the role of patient selection, education, and postoperative care.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly alters gastrointestinal anatomy and function, posing risks of malnutrition and nutritional deficiencies, but these can be largely prevented with proper patient selection, preoperative education, and postoperative follow-up. Nurses play a critical role in monitoring and reinforcing dietary compliance to avoid deficiencies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the clinical and cost-effectiveness of a vein bypass-first strategy versus a best endovascular treatment-first strategy for preventing major amputation or death in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischaemia.
results_summary: The best endovascular treatment-first strategy showed better amputation-free survival, driven by fewer deaths, and was more cost-effective than the vein bypass-first strategy. The economic evaluation indicated lower hospital costs and better quality-adjusted life-years for the endovascular approach.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb-threatening ischaemia due to atherosclerotic peripheral arterial disease requiring infra-popliteal revascularisation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different light durations and intensities, including far-red light exposure, affect the growth, phytochemical production, and hormonal responses of basil plants in controlled environments.
results_summary: The study found that low light intensity and long photoperiod (LI200/18) enhanced basil biomass and phytochemical production, while high light intensity and short photoperiod (LI400/9) negatively impacted growth. Far-red light reduced shoot growth and nutritional components like anthocyanins and flavonoids but increased stem elongation and soluble carbohydrates.
population_specificity: Basil plants grown in controlled environments.
effective_dosage: Light treatments included 200, 300, and 400 µmol m-2 s-1 for 18, 12, and 9 hours, respectively, with some plants exposed to additional 30 µmol m-2 s-1 far-red light.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how hydroponic cultivation with varying magnesium and manganese concentrations affects the nutritional, chemical, and bioactive properties of purple and green basil.
results_summary: Hydroponic cultivation with magnesium and manganese altered nutrient absorption, phenolic compound levels, and antioxidant activity in basil. Purple basil showed significant antiproliferative effects on tumor cell lines, while green basil exhibited antimicrobial properties and limited antiproliferative effects.
population_specificity: Purple and green basil plants grown hydroponically under controlled mineral conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (enriched or decreased concentrations of magnesium and manganese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Ocimum tenuiflorum (Holy Basil) phytochemicals in managing Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) by analyzing their binding interactions with Human Omentin-1.
results_summary: The study identified several phytochemicals (Luteolin, Madecassic acid, Ursolic acid, Stenocereol, Apigenin) with stronger binding affinity to Omentin-1 than Metformin. Molecular dynamics simulations suggested Stenocereol as a promising therapeutic candidate for T2DM.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers compared the safety and efficacy of surgical versus endovascular treatment for chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) in two randomized trials.
results_summary: The BEST-CLI trial found surgery superior due to fewer reinterventions, while BASIL-2 found endovascular therapy superior for amputation-free survival. Both studies highlighted high mortality rates in CLTI patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI), including those with lower leg lesions in BASIL-2.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 2.7 years (BEST-CLI) and 40 months (BASIL-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of basil seed gum (BSG) edible coating and ultrasonic pretreatment on frying time, oil uptake, texture, color, and sensory attributes of fried potato slices.
results_summary: Edible coating with BSG and ultrasonic pretreatment significantly reduced oil uptake (from 26.92% to 14.56%) and improved sensory attributes, texture, and color parameters of fried potato slices. Higher ultrasonic power (150 W) yielded the best results in appearance, odor, texture, flavor, and overall acceptance.
population_specificity: Fried potato slices (in vitro food model)
effective_dosage: Ultrasonic pretreatment at 75 W and 150 W

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of an ethanol extract of Ocimum basilicum L. (EEOb) against Ehrlich's experimental tumor (EET) in mice.
results_summary: Treatment with EEOb at 100 mg/kg reduced tumor growth and the number of AgNORs in solid Ehrlich tumor, likely due to apoptosis induction via Bcl-2 reduction. The study concluded that daily EEOb administration can inhibit EET growth by promoting tumor cell apoptosis.
population_specificity: Swiss mice inoculated with Ehrlich's experimental tumor cells.
study_duration: 28 days (treatment began 24 hours after tumor inoculation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to classify the types and severity of stress (drought, salinity, and chilling) in sweet basil using bioimpedance spectroscopy and vegetation indices combined with machine learning models.
results_summary: The study found that integrating bioimpedance and vegetation indices improved stress classification accuracy, with the support vector machine (SVM) model achieving the highest accuracy (0.90). Early-stage stress classification was also possible for drought and salinity with high accuracies (0.95 and 0.93, respectively).
population_specificity: Sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) leaves exposed to stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand why a vein bypass (VB) first revascularization strategy was associated with higher mortality compared to a best endovascular treatment (BET) first strategy in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia.
results_summary: The study found that the VB group had a higher proportion of cardiac-related deaths (35%) compared to the BET group (21%), contributing to the excess mortality observed. The excess cardiac deaths were consistent throughout follow-up, with no evidence of non-proportional hazards.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia requiring infrapopliteal revascularization, with or without femoropopliteal involvement.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical/interventional procedures, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum) leaf extract could enhance regenerative responses in Nicotiana tabacum leaf explants and elucidate its biochemical interactions with endogenous plant growth regulators.
results_summary: Tulsi leaf extract significantly improved shoot production, with the 20% treatment showing the highest efficacy. Increased levels of endogenous IAA, zeatin, and ABA were observed, suggesting their role in stress mitigation and somatic embryo-like structure induction.
population_specificity: Nicotiana tabacum (tobacco) leaf explants in vitro.
study_duration: Observations were made on days 10, 15, and 25 in culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the influence of microwave treatment on the viscosity and rheological behavior of Basil seed gum dispersion.
results_summary: The study found that microwave treatment reduced the apparent viscosity of Basil seed gum dispersion and altered its rheological properties, with the Power Law model best describing its behavior. Consistency coefficient decreased and flow behavior index increased significantly with longer microwave treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on Basil seed gum dispersion)
study_duration: Microwave treatment durations of 0, 1, 2, and 3 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer effects of extracellular vesicles (EVs) purified from Basil leaves, specifically their ability to induce apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells.
results_summary: Basil EVs (BasEVs) demonstrated significant cytotoxic effects on pancreatic cancer cell line MIA PaCa-2, reducing cell viability and clonogenic potential at concentrations of 80 and 160 μg/mL. Apoptotic gene (Bax) and protein expression were upregulated in BasEV-treated groups compared to controls.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cell line MIA PaCa-2 (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of salt stress response in sweet basil and identify key genes for improving salt tolerance.
results_summary: Salt stress inhibited seed germination, seedling growth, and chlorophyll synthesis in sweet basil. Overexpression of ObWRKY16 and ObPAL2 enhanced salt tolerance in transgenic Arabidopsis, suggesting their potential for developing salt-resistant basil cultivars.
population_specificity: Sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) and transgenic Arabidopsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sweet basil leaf powder (SBLP) as a natural iron source for treating anemia in adolescent girls.
results_summary: The study found that SBLP-fortified cookies significantly improved hematological parameters (Hb, Hct, serum iron, ferritin, etc.) in anemic girls, with group B3 (16g SBLP/100g) showing the highest serum iron levels and transferrin saturation. Serum ferritin was better in the FeSO4 group (B1) than SBLP (B3), but both treatments outperformed the control.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls with anemia (aged not specified).
effective_dosage: 16g sweet basil leaf powder (SBLP) per 100g cookies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) and spirulina extract on the growth, oil production, and antioxidant activity of French basil.
results_summary: Foliar application of CuNPs and spirulina extract significantly improved growth, oil production, and photosynthetic pigment accumulation in basil, with the best results at 500 mg/L CuNPs and 1.5 g/L spirulina extract. However, combining CuNPs with spirulina reduced antioxidant activity compared to CuNPs alone.
population_specificity: French basil plants
effective_dosage: CuNPs at 500, 1000, and 1500 mg/L; spirulina extract at 0.5, 1, and 1.5 g/L

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of traditional basil oil with diclofenac gel in treating knee osteoarthritis symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between basil oil and diclofenac gel in improving knee osteoarthritis symptoms, but both treatments showed significant within-group improvements in pain, function, and other measures.
population_specificity: 100 patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different LED light spectra affect biomass, antioxidant compounds, and production value in various basil cultivars and genotypes.
results_summary: The study found that blue lighting enhanced antioxidant capacity, phenolic compounds, and vitamin C in the Ablagh genotype, while red lighting improved starch synthesis in Red Rubin and flavonoids in Violeto. The highest biomass and carbohydrate synthesis were observed under specific light treatments.
population_specificity: Basil microgreens (Red Rubin, Violeto, Kapoor cultivars, and Ablagh genotype).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess bioactive peptides from defatted lemon basil seeds for their ability to inhibit pancreatic lipase, reduce lipid accumulation, and suppress adipogenesis.
results_summary: The study identified a peptide (GRSPDTHSG) with strong lipase inhibitory activity (IC50 0.255 mM) and demonstrated its ability to reduce lipid accumulation in 3T3-L1 cells without cytotoxicity, while also downregulating key adipogenic markers (PPAR-γ, SREBP-1c) and enhancing AMPK-α phosphorylation.
population_specificity: In vitro (3T3-L1 cells) and molecular docking studies.
effective_dosage: IC50 of 0.255 mM for GRSPDTHSG peptide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the encapsulation of basil essential oil (BEO) with β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) and assess its insecticidal properties against the Colorado potato beetle (CPB).
results_summary: The study found that BEO, when complexed with β-CD, exhibited continuous volatile emission over 24 hours and altered the developmental dynamics of CPB larvae, though the initial increase in proteolytic activity was not sustained.
population_specificity: Colorado potato beetle (CPB) larvae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of horsetail extract (containing high silicon) on the growth, phytochemical traits, and essential oil composition of sweet basil.
results_summary: The study found that increasing concentrations of horsetail extract significantly improved growth traits (e.g., plant height, leaf number, fresh/dry weight) and phytochemical content (e.g., total phenol, flavonoid, anthocyanin, antioxidant activity). Essential oil content and specific compounds (eugenol, 1,8-cineole, linalool) also increased, while others (methyl eugenol, (Z)-caryophyllene) decreased.
population_specificity: Sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) plants at the 6-8 leaf stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate bioaccumulation and depuration of MC-LR in basil, verify possible detoxification mechanisms, and detect natural MC-LR occurrence in market-sourced basil.
results_summary: Basil accumulated higher MC-LR levels in roots than leaves, with significant depuration observed in roots only. MC-LR was detected in one store-bought sample, marking the first reported occurrence in Belgian edible crops.
population_specificity: Hydroculture-grown basil plants and market-sourced basil samples (n=50).
effective_dosage: 5, 20, and 50 μg L-1 MC-LR in Hoagland solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of sweet basil (SB) leaf and seed extracts in aluminum chloride-induced neurodegeneration in Drosophila melanogaster.
results_summary: SB leaf and seed extracts significantly improved survival, locomotor performance, and oxidative biomarkers while reducing ROS, TBARS, AChE, and MAO activities in AlCl3-exposed flies. SB leaf showed better neuroprotective effects, likely due to higher phenolic content.
population_specificity: Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) with induced neurodegeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biochemical and growth changes in basil seedlings exposed to silver nanoparticles and silver nitrate.
results_summary: Exposure to silver nanoparticles and silver nitrate reduced basil growth and chlorophyll content but increased antioxidant compounds like phenols, carotenoids, and anthocyanins. However, oxidative stress markers (MDA and H2O2) also increased, indicating incomplete mitigation of stress.
population_specificity: Basil seedlings (Ocimum basilicum L.)
effective_dosage: 0, 40, and 80 ppm of silver nanoparticles and silver nitrate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telephone-delivered behavioural activation intervention (BASIL+) could mitigate depression and loneliness in socially isolated older adults during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced depression severity (PHQ-9 scores) at 3 months compared to usual care, with an adjusted mean difference of -1.65 (p=0.0003). No adverse events were reported, and the intervention was deemed effective for short-term symptom reduction.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65+ with social isolation, depression (PHQ-9 ≥5), and multiple long-term conditions.
effective_dosage: Up to eight weekly telephone sessions.

study_goal: The researchers evaluated the effectiveness of in-package radiofrequency (RF) steaming for Salmonella inactivation on dried basil leaves and prevention of cross-contamination postprocessing.
results_summary: In-package RF steaming of dried basil leaves for 40 seconds achieved more than a 5-log reduction of Salmonella, demonstrating effective pasteurization and prevention of cross-contamination. The steam vent sealed the package properly posttreatment, protecting the product from external contamination.
population_specificity: Dried basil leaves (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ZnO nanoparticles, SiO2 nanoparticles, and date palm pollen extract (DPPE) on reducing NPK fertilizer usage while enhancing basil plant production, essential oil yield, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The most effective treatment (½ NPK RD + 20 g/L DPPE + 2.0 g/L ZnO NPs) significantly improved vegetative traits, essential oil yield, and antioxidant activity compared to the control. Essential oil composition varied among treatments, with major compounds like estragole, methyl eugenol, and linalool identified.
population_specificity: Basil plants (Ocimum basilicum) in field experiments during the 2021 and 2022 seasons.
effective_dosage: ZnO NPs (1.5 and 2.0 g/L), SiO2 NPs (100 and 150 mg/L), DPPE (10 and 20 g/L), alone or combined with ¾ or ½ NPK recommended dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological, ecological, and biochemical effects of Serendipita indica and algal extracts, individually and in combination, on basil plant growth and performance.
results_summary: The combined treatment of Chlorella vulgaris and Serendipita indica significantly increased chlorophyll index (61.7%), essential oil, and antioxidant values in basil, while some algal extracts inhibited S. indica colonization. Synergistic effects were observed, enhancing basil growth and productivity.
population_specificity: Basil plants (Ocimum basilicum L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of basil leaf ethanol extract on VEGF expression and endometriosis lesion severity in a mouse model.
results_summary: Basil leaf ethanol extract at doses of 0.21 mg/g-BW and 0.42 mg/g-BW significantly reduced VEGF expression and showed a non-significant trend in reducing endometriosis lesion severity. Higher doses (0.84 mg/g-BW) were less effective.
population_specificity: Female mice aged 2-3 months, weighing 20-30 grams.
study_duration: 14-day treatment period, with tissue collection on day 29.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of gut microbiota in the anticonvulsant effect of basil oil (BO) using antibiotic-depleted and altered germ-free mice in a PTZ-induced seizure model.
results_summary: Cocktail antibiotic pre-treatment reversed the anticonvulsant effect of BO by increasing seizure frequency and duration, while single antibiotics completely abolished BO's effect. The study also found that BO administration did not influence microbial composition but noted an elevated Firmicutes-to-Bacteroidetes ratio in microbiota-depleted groups, which may contribute to the loss of anticonvulsant effects.
population_specificity: Antibiotic-depleted and altered germ-free mice in a PTZ-induced seizure model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different supplemental lighting (LED and HPS) parameters and durations on greenhouse hydroponic basil production, focusing on biomass yield, nutrient bioaccumulation, and light use efficiency.
results_summary: Supplemental lighting treatments and growing seasons significantly impacted basil biomass and nutrient accumulation, with some treatments yielding less than the non-supplemented control. Seasonal variation in ambient sunlight, spectral quality, and application schedule influenced biomass and nutrient concentrations, with November showing the highest yields and January the lowest.
population_specificity: Greenhouse hydroponic basil (Ocimum basilicum var. 'Genovese').
effective_dosage: Supplemental light treatments provided 100 µmol·m-2·s-1, with varying durations (3h, 6h, 9h, 12h, 18h, 24h).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over growing seasons (November and January).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Basil tea could alleviate psychological and physical side effects of radioactive iodine therapy (RAIT) in patients with differentiated thyroid cancer.
results_summary: Basil tea significantly reduced anxiety scores and improved oral mucosal conditions and salivary gland function compared to the control group. It also lowered cariogenic bacteria, ammonia, protein, and occult blood levels in the oral cavity.
population_specificity: 44 patients with differentiated thyroid cancer after total thyroidectomy.
effective_dosage: 180 mL of Basil tea prepared from 2.0 g of Holy basil leaves, consumed after each meal.
study_duration: Four days, starting on the day RAIT was performed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the generalisability of the BASIL-2 trial outcomes and contextualize the findings within the broader chronic limb threatening ischaemia (CLTI) patient population.
results_summary: The study found that only a small subset (20%) of CLTI patients requiring infrapopliteal revascularisation were randomised into BASIL-2, with most deemed unsuitable for randomisation due to various anatomical and operational reasons. Differences in outcomes between IP bypass and IP BET outside BASIL-2 were not statistically tested due to small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb threatening ischaemia (CLTI) requiring infrapopliteal revascularisation.
study_duration: Follow-up data were censored on 14 December 2022, with patient recruitment between 24 June 2014 and 31 July 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of copper (Cu) and vegetable protein hydrolysate (VPH) treatments on the growth, photosynthetic performance, and mineral content of Genovese basil.
results_summary: The combined VPH+Cu-VPH treatment significantly increased fresh yield (16.3%) and improved photosynthetic performance (ACO2 +29%, Fv/Fm +7%). It also enhanced mineral content (Mg, Mn, Ca, Fe) and reduced oxidative stress compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Genovese basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) grown in protected conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare hydroponically and soil-grown basil in terms of resilience to downy mildew and heat treatment, as well as storage and shelf-life performance.
results_summary: Hydroponically grown basil showed greater resistance to downy mildew but was more sensitive to heat and browning during storage, resulting in poorer shelf-life performance compared to soil-grown basil. Hydroponic basil also had higher antioxidant capacity at harvest and after storage.
population_specificity: Basil plants (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify cadmium (Cd) stress-responsive genes in clove basil (Ocimum gratissimum L.) to understand its adaptation mechanisms and improve its use in phytoremediation of Cd-contaminated soils.
results_summary: High Cd levels negatively impacted clove basil growth and physiology, with Cd accumulation increasing in tissues. Transcriptomic analysis revealed over 1,800 differentially expressed genes (DEGs), highlighting key pathways like MAPK signaling and plant-pathogen interaction, and identified 78 transcription factors potentially involved in Cd stress response.
population_specificity: Clove basil seedlings (Ocimum gratissimum L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether periodic short-duration supplementary far red light treatments could improve chilling tolerance in live potted basil grown in commercial glasshouses.
results_summary: Four days of midday supplementary far red light at the end of production significantly enhanced basil's tolerance to cold (4 °C), reducing visual damage and physiological markers of chilling injury while maintaining higher antioxidant levels. Gene expression analysis suggested mechanisms like starch conversion to raffinose sugars, anthocyanin biosynthesis, and gibberellin signaling inactivation contributed to this effect.
population_specificity: Live potted basil plants grown in a large-scale commercial glasshouse.
effective_dosage: Periodic midday supplementary far red light for four days.
study_duration: Four days of light treatment followed by 24 hours of cold exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Basil landraces are better adapted to water-limited environments compared to commercial cultivars.
results_summary: Limited water availability reduced dry matter yield by 20% and essential oil yield by 21% across all genotypes. Landraces Athos white spike (AWS) and Gigas white spike (GWS) performed best under water-limited conditions, indicating suitability for dryland climates.
population_specificity: Basil genotypes (landraces and commercial cultivars) grown under varying irrigation levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Ocimum Sanctum (Basil) and other disinfectants on bond integrity and microleakage in resin restorations.
results_summary: Ocimum Sanctum (Group 4) showed the lowest microleakage (0.471 nm) and highest bond strength (23.06±0.21 MPa) among the tested disinfectants. It outperformed Phycocyanin and Ti-sapphire laser in both bond integrity and microleakage reduction.
population_specificity: Extracted human mandibular molars with ICDAS caries scores of 4 and 5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different supplemental lighting spectra (narrowband blue/red ratios and broadband sources) influence flavor volatiles in hydroponic basil.
results_summary: The study found that spectral quality of supplemental lighting directly affects basil aroma volatile concentrations, with specific B/R ratios and discrete wavelengths altering the aroma profile. Optimal conditions were identified as 450 and 660 nm wavelengths at a 10B/90R ratio under 100-200 µmol.m-2.s-1 for 12-24 hours daily.
population_specificity: Hydroponic basil (Ocimum basilicum var. Italian Large Leaf) grown under greenhouse conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how salinity stress affects yield, phytochemical composition, antioxidant activity, and aroma profile in three basil cultivars.
results_summary: Salt stress reduced fresh yield in two cultivars (Italiano Classico and Dark Opal) but not in Purple Ruffles. Salinity increased β-carotene, lutein, antioxidant activity, and nitrogen content in Purple Ruffles, while altering VOC composition, with linalool negatively affected in Italiano Classico and Dark Opal but estragole unaffected in Purple Ruffles.
population_specificity: Three basil cultivars (Dark Opal, Italiano Classico, Purple Ruffles) grown hydroponically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a production method for high-quality Genova basil tea with optimal antioxidant properties and to evaluate the effects of processing conditions on its composition and properties.
results_summary: The study found that Genova basil leaves and flowers had higher antioxidant values, steaming for 2 minutes preserved polyphenol content and antioxidant properties, and freeze-drying without steaming retained key aroma components. Optimal drying temperature was ≤40 °C for maintaining quality.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant material study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of basil-synthesized zinc oxide nanoparticles (B-ZnO-NPs) in improving wheat germination, plant growth, and antibacterial properties.
results_summary: B-ZnO-NPs improved wheat germination to 100% at 400 mg/L concentration and showed increased Zn+2 uptake in plants. They also demonstrated antibacterial properties, with greater sensitivity in S. aureus than E. coli.
population_specificity: Wheat plants (Triticum spp.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of vein bypass versus best endovascular treatment as the first revascularization strategy for preventing major amputation and death in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia.
results_summary: The study found that a best endovascular treatment first strategy was associated with better amputation-free survival, largely due to fewer deaths in this group compared to the vein bypass group. Major amputation or death occurred in 63% of the vein bypass group versus 53% in the best endovascular treatment group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia due to atherosclerotic disease requiring infra-popliteal revascularization, with or without additional proximal infra-inguinal procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ohmic-heating and ultrasonic pre-treatment methods for enhancing essential oil extraction from Indian basil leaves compared to conventional methods.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasonic pre-treatment coupled with ohmic-heating hydro-distillation (UAOHD) significantly improved essential oil yield, reduced extraction time by ~86%, and lowered energy consumption by 74% compared to conventional methods. UAOHD outperformed other methods (UACHD, OHD, CHD) in terms of efficiency and yield.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on plant leaves).
effective_dosage: Not specified (voltage gradients of 22.5 V/cm for Indian basil).
study_duration: Not specified (extraction times varied by method, e.g., 3.5 h for OHD, 5 h for CHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of cold plasma treatment on basil seed gum (BSG) properties and its use in functional edible films.
results_summary: Cold plasma treatment modified BSG's structural and rheological properties, enhancing hydrophobicity and viscosity. Modified BSG successfully produced stable edible films with encapsulated vitamin D3 and tannic acid, showing higher stability than free forms.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether OA-POSS nanoparticles could mitigate the harmful effects of salt stress on sweet basil plants and improve their growth and essential oil profile.
results_summary: OA-POSS nanoparticles reduced salinity-induced damage by enhancing photosynthetic pigment content, adjusting chlorophyll fluorescence, and boosting antioxidant activity. The optimal concentration was 25 mg L-1, which improved estragole content in basil essential oil under salt stress.
population_specificity: Sweet basil plants subjected to salt stress (50 and 100 mM NaCl).
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 mg L-1 OA-POSS NPs (foliar application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of estragole (EST) isolated from basil leaves, radiolabeled with 131I, for targeting and uptake in human brain cancer cell lines (medulloblastoma and glioblastoma-astrocytoma).
results_summary: The study found that 131I-EST showed significant uptake in brain cancer cell lines, suggesting potential for diagnostic or therapeutic applications. Cytotoxicity and cell uptake studies supported its bio-affinity for these cancer cells.
population_specificity: Human medulloblastoma (DAOY) and human glioblastoma-astrocytoma (U-87 MG) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of starch-based bioplastic residues on the growth and biochemical parameters of basil.
results_summary: Basil plants exposed to bioplastic showed stunted growth, reduced chlorophyll, protein, ascorbic acid, and glucose content, and increased oxidative stress. The bioplastic also altered soil properties, increasing electrical conductivity and reducing cation exchange capacity.
population_specificity: Basil plants grown under controlled experimental conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the germination potential of sweet basil seeds using radio-frequency cold plasma treatment with Ar + O2 feed gas.
results_summary: The study found that plasma treatment significantly improved germination percentage (up to 89%, a 32.3% enhancement over control), water absorption, carbohydrate and protein content, and antioxidant activity. Growth parameters (SVI I and SVI II) also showed substantial improvements (37% and 133% amplification, respectively).
population_specificity: Ocimum basilicum (sweet basil) seeds
effective_dosage: RF source power (60 W, 150 W, 240 W), process pressure (0.2 mbar, 0.4 mbar, 0.6 mbar), and treatment time (5 min, 10 min, 15 min) in various combinations
study_duration: Treatment times ranged from 5 to 15 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effect of basil seeds and gum arabic on healing, inflammation, and oxidative stress in rats with experimentally induced colitis.
results_summary: Treatment with basil seeds and gum arabic reduced colon damage, oxidative stress markers (MDA, MPO), and pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNFα, IL6, IL17) while increasing antioxidant enzymes (SOD, GPx) and anti-inflammatory cytokine (IL10). The combination showed significant anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, accelerating colon healing.
population_specificity: Male rats with acetic acid-induced colitis.
effective_dosage: 1 mg/kg rectally (combined basil seeds and gum arabic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of behavioural activation (BASIL-C19 trial) in reducing depression and loneliness in older adults with long-term conditions during COVID-19.
results_summary: The BASIL-C19 trial showed modest short-term reductions in depression and loneliness, with some evidence of long-term benefit. The living systematic review supported these findings, indicating cognitive and/or behavioural interventions have short-term efficacy for loneliness and depression.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years and older with long-term conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant properties of ethanoic basil extract in inhibiting oxidation in crude sesame oil and its potential as a substitute for inorganic antioxidants.
results_summary: Basil extract significantly inhibited oxidation (16.38%-90%) in crude sesame oil, maintaining peroxide, para-anisidine, and total oxidation values below tolerable limits. However, its antioxidant efficacy declined during prolonged storage, especially at elevated temperatures.
population_specificity: Crude sesame oil samples (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of integrating solar-powered desalination, aquaculture, and agriculture to grow basil using fish effluents as fertilizers.
results_summary: The study found that basil grown with fish effluents and foliar nutrient application achieved the highest fresh and dry weights (14.7 ton/ha and 4.7 ton/ha, respectively) and plant height (62 cm). The essential oil composition was dominated by linalool (55.5-61.6%) and other beneficial compounds.
population_specificity: Basil plants in an integrated desalination-aquaculture-agriculture system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different broad-bandwidth LED light spectra and intensities on the growth, yield, marketability, and volatile organic compound (VOC) profiles of four basil cultivars.
results_summary: Higher light intensities (IHigh) accelerated growth and increased yields but induced light avoidance responses in green-leafed cultivars, while lower intensities (ILow) improved visual quality and biomass efficiency for green-leafed cultivars. Purple-leafed cv. Dark Opal performed poorly under ILow but remained light-tolerant under IHigh, and VOC profiles varied significantly by cultivar and developmental stage.
population_specificity: Four Ocimum basilicum L. cultivars (cv. Anise, cv. Cinnamon, cv. Dark Opal, and cv. Thai Magic) grown under controlled-environment horticulture conditions.
effective_dosage: Light intensities ranged from ~100 to ~200 µmol m-2 s-1 (ILow) and ~200 to ~400 µmol m-2 s-1 (IHigh).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ascorbic acid, mycorrhiza fungus, and Azospirillium bacteria on basil's growth and essential oil production under drought stress conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the highest biological yield occurred under 40 mm drought stress with mycorrhiza application, showing a 70% increase compared to 100 mm stress without biofertilizers. Ascorbic acid improved essential oil yield by 10% under 100 mm drought stress.
population_specificity: Basil plants (Ocimum basilicum L.) grown under controlled drought stress conditions in Shahriar, Iran.
