effective_dosage: Ascorbic acid applied via foliar spray two days after irrigation; biofertilizer application methods included seed treatments (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of potassium bicarbonate (KHCO3) on morphophysiological parameters, phenolics content, and antioxidant activity of basil under drought conditions.
results_summary: Potassium bicarbonate application significantly increased chlorophyll content, fresh and dry weight, phenolics content, and antioxidant activity in drought-stressed basil cultivars. Principal component and hierarchical clustering analyses confirmed positive relationships between treatment and measured parameters.
population_specificity: Sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) seedlings with 5-6 true leaves.
study_duration: Three days after treatment, followed by drought stress assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of different light intensities and fertilization on the growth and antioxidant activity of basil.
results_summary: Basil's antioxidant activity was most affected by 150 µmol m-2 s-1 PPFD lighting and the absence of fertilization, suggesting optimal conditions for enhancing its antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum, 'Opal') grown in a greenhouse under controlled light and temperature conditions.
effective_dosage: Fertilized twice a week with a complex fertilizer (NPK 3-1-3).
study_duration: The study was conducted in May, but the exact duration of the intervention is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Indonesian basil maceration on gonad development and uterine preparation for implantation in mature female albino rats.
results_summary: Basil maceration (1% and 5%) significantly increased serum estradiol and progesterone levels, improved uterine weight, diameter, and vascularization, and enhanced follicle growth, suggesting better preparation for implantation. No significant difference was observed in FSH levels between treated and control groups.
population_specificity: 8-week-old female Sprague-Dawley rats at the diestrus stage of the estrus cycle.
effective_dosage: 1% and 5% basil maceration in mineral drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how basil (Ocimum basilicum) affects the biological control of aphids by the predatory lacewing Chrysopa pallens in greenhouse settings.
results_summary: Basil enhanced the longevity and early-age fecundity of C. pallens when prey was present and improved lacewing colonization rates by 72-92% near aphid-infested eggplants. Higher basil planting density and intercropping arrangements led to the highest lacewing colonization rates and faster aphid decline.
population_specificity: Predatory lacewings (Chrysopa pallens) and peach aphids (Myzus persicae) in a greenhouse environment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether UV-A radiation could improve both yield and quality (phenolic content) of sweet basil in a controlled indoor production environment.
results_summary: Mild UV-A intensity (10-20 W·m-2) improved biomass and phenolic content, while higher intensity (30 W·m-2) reduced growth and photosynthesis. Phenolic compounds were highest under 20 W·m-2 UV-A.
population_specificity: Sweet basil plants grown in an indoor controlled environment.
effective_dosage: UV-A intensity treatments of 0, 10, 20, and 30 W·m-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of NPK Slow-Release Fertilizer Coated by Starch (NPK-SRFS) at different rates on the growth, yield, and essential oil components of basil.
results_summary: NPK-SRFS treatments significantly increased the number of buds and leaves per plant compared to the control, with varying effects on plant height and leaf area. The fertilizer also influenced chlorophyll content and essential oil composition, particularly Methyl Chavicol and α-trans-Bergamotene levels.
population_specificity: Basil plants grown in Northern Vietnam.
effective_dosage: Different rates of NPK-SRFS (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer activity of basil and its components, focusing on its potential role in cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Basil extracts demonstrated potential anticancer effects, including cytotoxicity, apoptosis induction, tumor growth slowdown, and cell cycle arrest, with effective dosages ranging from 50 to 500 µg/mL in vitro and 4 mg/mL as aqueous extract or essential oil up to 200 µg/mL in vivo. Human studies showed effects at 1 to 2.5 mg daily on reducing cytokines activity.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models) and general human vital activities (limited human data).
effective_dosage: 4 mg/mL (aqueous extract), 50–500 µg/mL (essential oil), 1–2.5 mg daily (human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether varying percentages of blue light and photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD) affect the accumulation of antioxidants in basil and its chilling tolerance.
results_summary: The study found that the percentage of blue light had little effect on antioxidant levels in basil at harvest, and no interactive effect with PPFD was observed. Antioxidant levels decreased during postharvest storage, more so at 4°C than at 12°C, and chilling tolerance in the purple cultivar improved under higher PPFD.
population_specificity: Green (cv. Dolly) and purple (cv. Rosie) basil plants.
effective_dosage: Blue light percentages (9%, 33%, 65%, 100%) and PPFD levels (100 or 300 μmol m-2 s-1).
study_duration: 5-day End-Of-Production (EOP) treatment or continuous throughout the growth cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate alternative formulations (preservative agents and thermic treatment) to better preserve the color of basil-based semi-finished products during shelf-life.
results_summary: Blast chilling combined with ascorbic acid proved most effective in preserving the color of basil-based products. Spectrophotometric analysis and CIELab parameters were used to monitor color variations, with multivariate statistical analysis supporting the findings.
population_specificity: Basil-based semi-finished products (industrial food products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antibacterial mechanism of basil essential oil (BEO) against Listeria monocytogenes to provide a theoretical basis for natural antibacterial agents.
results_summary: BEO demonstrated strong antibacterial activity against L. monocytogenes, reducing bacterial counts to undetectable levels after 8 hours. It increased cell membrane permeability, caused leakage of intracellular proteins and DNA, inhibited key enzymes in the EMP pathway, and induced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: In vitro study on Listeria monocytogenes bacteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a brief psychological intervention (Behavioral Activation) delivered remotely could mitigate depression and loneliness in older adults with long-term conditions during COVID-19 social isolation.
results_summary: The study is a trial in progress, so no results are reported in the abstract. It builds on a successful pilot trial and will evaluate clinical and cost-effectiveness of the intervention.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 with two or more long-term conditions or clinically extremely vulnerable to COVID-19, scoring ≥5 on the PHQ9.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (psychological intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Up to eight intervention sessions (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of basil seed gum as part of an edible coating in maintaining postharvest quality and safety of tomatoes.
results_summary: Coating tomatoes with basil seed gum (0.1%) and Arabic gum at pH 5.6 significantly improved vitamin C retention, reduced weight loss, and delayed quality deterioration during storage. Basil seed gum at 0.1% was among the best treatments for extending tomato storability.
population_specificity: Postharvest tomatoes stored at 4°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the repellent and acaricidal activity of essential oils from three basil varieties against blacklegged ticks and American dog ticks.
results_summary: Basil essential oils, particularly var. Jolina at 15% vol/vol, repelled 96% of ticks for up to 2 hours, while var. Aroma 2 combined with rock dust achieved 100% tick mortality within 24 hours. The most common compounds detected were linalool, sabinene, eugenol, and estragole.
population_specificity: Blacklegged ticks (Ixodes scapularis) and American dog ticks (Dermacentor variabilis) in laboratory conditions.
effective_dosage: 15% vol/vol for repellency (var. Jolina), 10% wt/wt for acaricidal activity (var. Aroma 2 with rock dust).
study_duration: Up to 24 hours post-exposure for acaricidal tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different LED light spectrum ratios affect the growth, photosynthesis, secondary metabolite synthesis, and antioxidant capacity of two cultivars of holy basil (Ocimum tenuiflorum).
results_summary: The study found that specific light ratios (3R:1B, 1R:3B, and 2R:1G:2B) differentially influenced biomass accumulation, photosynthetic activity, pigment content, and antioxidant capacity in green and red holy basil. For example, 3R:1B promoted biomass and photosynthesis in green holy basil, while 1R:3B enhanced antioxidant capacity and biomass in red holy basil.
population_specificity: Holy basil plants (Ocimum tenuiflorum) cultivated under controlled environmental conditions.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (light spectrum ratios used: 3R:1B, 1R:1B, 1R:3B, and 2R:1G:2B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a nano-based formulation combining vitamin E, quercetin, and basil oil for treating Alzheimer's disorder (AD) via intranasal administration.
results_summary: The study suggests that the combination of vitamin E, quercetin, and basil oil in a nanoformulation may effectively treat AD by leveraging their antioxidant properties and synergistic effects, while intranasal delivery enhances bioavailability and reduces systemic side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not mention a specific study population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytochemicals, essential oils, and pharmacological activities of Ocimum gratissimum (clove basil) to assess its potential therapeutic effects against various diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Ocimum gratissimum contains numerous bioactive compounds with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, hepatoprotective, antidiabetic, and antimicrobial properties, demonstrating strong preventive and therapeutic effects against several diseases. However, further human clinical trials are needed to establish effective and safe doses.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro studies reviewed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sous-vide heat treatment on the volatile compounds profile, sensory quality, and color of basil infusions compared to conventional preparation.
results_summary: No significant differences were found in taste and aroma intensity across different temperatures. Sous-vide samples showed higher alkane content and darker, less green/yellow leaves, with pronounced aroma changes at higher temperatures. Conventional infusion resembled sous-vide at 65°C, while 75°C and 85°C were distinct.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on basil infusions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the hypoglycemic and antihyperglycemic effects of basil extracts, both alone and in combination with MKC acid, delivered via microvesicles in alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: A seven-day treatment with basil aqueous extract and a combination of basil and MKC acid significantly reduced blood glucose levels in diabetic rats, demonstrating hypoglycemic and antihyperglycemic effects. Microvesicles enhanced the hypolipidemic action of basil extract with MKC acid.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Basil extract (200 mg/kg), MKC acid (4 mg/kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if eugenol, a component of holy basil (Tulsi), could inhibit the interaction between SARS-CoV-2 spike S1 and ACE2, potentially offering a treatment for COVID-19.
results_summary: Eugenol selectively bound to spike S1 (not ACE2), inhibited pseudotyped SARS-CoV-2 entry, reduced inflammatory cytokine expression in lung cells, and improved symptoms in spike S1-intoxicated mice.
population_specificity: Human ACE2-expressing HEK293 cells, human A549 lung cells, and SARS-CoV-2 spike S1-intoxicated mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of basil seed extract-loaded solid lipid nanoparticles (BSE-SLNp) in enhancing bioavailability and metabolic functions in adipocytes and vascular smooth muscle cells.
results_summary: BSE-SLNp showed no toxicity up to 64 μg/ml and enhanced metabolic function at 4 μg/ml, improving mitochondrial efficiency, fatty acid oxidation, and antioxidant capacity while reducing oxidative stress and inflammation in treated cells.
population_specificity: Human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs), preadipocytes, and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).
effective_dosage: 4 μg/ml (effective dose), up to 64 μg/ml (tested higher dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Behavioral Activation (BA) could mitigate psychological impacts of COVID-19 isolation in older adults with long-term conditions.
results_summary: The study found that BA showed potential benefits in reducing loneliness at 3 months, though effects on depression and anxiety were less clear. The intervention was feasible to deliver remotely and had high participant engagement.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 years with two or more long-term conditions, predominantly White (95.8%) and mostly female (61.5%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (BA involved a median of 6 sessions out of 8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inducing systemic resistance in plants (via biological or chemical elicitors) could reduce Salmonella colonization in basil and lettuce leaves.
results_summary: The study found that microbial inducers like Rhodotorula glutinis significantly reduced Salmonella populations in basil leaves, while some chemical elicitors also showed inhibitory effects. Enhanced defense gene expression (PR1) was sustained longer with elicitor treatment compared to Salmonella induction alone.
population_specificity: Basil and lettuce plants (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (root treatments with microbial/chemical elicitors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Mn, Zn, Cu, and Fe, applied as EDTA chelates, on reducing sweet basil downy mildew (SBDM) severity under various conditions.
results_summary: Spray applications of EDTA-chelated microelements (Fe, Mn, Zn, Cu, Mo) reduced SBDM severity, with Mn-EDTA and Zn-EDTA showing significant efficacy (46-71% reduction) under commercial-like conditions. Combining Mg with Mn-EDTA and Zn-EDTA did not enhance disease reduction, but combining microelements with fungicides provided synergistic control.
population_specificity: Potted basil plants, semi-commercial, and commercial-like field conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of soaking and germination on nutritional, bioactive, and anti-nutritional components of lima and adzuki beans.
results_summary: Germination increased protein digestibility, antioxidant activity, reducing power, flavonoid content, and metal chelating capacity while decreasing anti-nutrients like phytic acid, tannins, and trypsin inhibitors. The findings suggest germinated bean flour could enhance functional bakery products and address protein deficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-intensity ultrasound (HIU) supplemented with hydrogen peroxide could improve the germination process and nutritional quality of red kidney beans.
results_summary: The 350 W-10 min HIU treatment significantly improved germination rate, sprout length, and nutritional content (e.g., increased protein, phenolic compounds, and antioxidative capacity) while reducing antinutrients like phytic acid and tannins. The treatment also enhanced amino acid composition and protein digestibility.
population_specificity: Red kidney beans (no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of steaming time on fatty acids, free fatty acids, proximate levels, and antioxidant activity in cocoa beans used for snack bar products.
results_summary: Longer steaming time affected fatty acids, saturated fatty acids, antioxidants, and proximate levels in cocoa beans. Steaming for 45 minutes increased oleic acid, palmitic acid, and antioxidant activity while reducing free fatty acids to meet international standards.
population_specificity: Cocoa beans (not human subjects)
effective_dosage: Seven steaming time intervals (specific durations not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal efficacy of biosynthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) against root rot fungi in common beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L.).
results_summary: AgNPs synthesized using Alhagi graecorum plant extract significantly inhibited fungal growth (75.93%-94.44%) and improved bean seedling health metrics (root length, shoot length, weight, vigor index) compared to controls. The nanoparticles were effective at concentrations of 75 μg/mL and 100 μg/mL in both in vitro and greenhouse conditions.
population_specificity: Common beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) infected with root rot fungi (Macrophomina phaseolina, Pythium graminicola, Rhizoctonia solani, Sclerotium rolfsii).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of different salinity treatments (NaCl and CaCl2 combinations) on yield, sensory quality, and bioactive compound accumulation in green and red basil cultivars across successive harvests.
results_summary: The green basil cultivar was more productive but more susceptible to salinity stress than the red cultivar. Adding CaCl2 reduced sodium accumulation and increased polyphenol content, while successive harvests improved phenol and vitamin C concentrations but reduced eucalyptol levels.
population_specificity: Hydroponically grown green and red basil cultivars.
effective_dosage: 12.5 mM NaCl + 8.33 mM CaCl2 (Moderate Mix), 25 mM NaCl (Moderate NaCl), 25 mM NaCl + 16.66 mM CaCl2 (High Mix), or 50 mM NaCl (High NaCl).
study_duration: Two successive harvests (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the functional and nutritional characteristics of Locust Bean Gum, its extraction methods, and its applications in the food sector, particularly in dairy product processing.
results_summary: The study found that Locust Bean Gum is rich in bioactive compounds beneficial for digestive health, cancer, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. It is widely used in food, especially dairy, for its water-binding and thickening properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid method to screen bioactive peptides from black beans with anti-α-glucosidase activity as potential alternatives to synthetic drugs for Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study identified three peptides (NNNPFKF, RADLPGVK, FLKEAFGV) with notable anti-α-glucosidase activity, with FLKEAFGV and RADLPGVK effectively lowering blood sugar levels in vivo, comparable to acarbose. The binding mechanism involves hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions, altering the α-helix structure of α-glucosidase.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: NNNPFKF (4.20 ± 0.11 mg/mL), RADLPGVK (2.83 ± 0.03 mg/mL), FLKEAFGV (1.32 ± 0.09 mg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetics and mechanism of action of Mucuna pruriens (MP) in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients, comparing its effects to a standard LD/CD preparation.
results_summary: MP prolonged ON time 2-fold compared to LD/CD, achieved higher LD concentrations without increasing dyskinesia, and showed a catechol-O-methyl transferase inhibitory effect. MP was found to be as effective as LD, worked faster and longer, and did not increase dyskinesia.
population_specificity: Seven patients with Parkinson's disease attending the researchers' institution.
effective_dosage: 11 g of MP reagent (containing 4.02% LD per MP powder) and 100/10 mg LD/CD tablets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify engaging headlines that would encourage people to consider plant protein (specifically beans) over red meat, focusing on motivators (health vs. environmental reasons) and barriers (family preferences, knowledge, or cooking skills).
results_summary: Headlines emphasizing health and family were more likely to be clicked, while those containing the word "beans" performed significantly worse. Health-related headlines outperformed environmental ones, and family-oriented headlines slightly outperformed those focused on skills or knowledge.
population_specificity: 144 survey respondents from an urban Minnesota community who live with at least one other person and eat meat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of silicon (Si) doses applied via fertigation under various water regimes, with and without potassium fertilization, on gas exchange, water use efficiency, and growth of common beans in field conditions.
results_summary: Fertigation application of Si improved plant performance, particularly under severe water deficit, enhancing relative water content, leaf water potential, and membrane resistance, which positively impacted pigment content and gas exchange rates. Optimal Si doses varied with water regimes (6.6–7.1 kg ha⁻¹), mitigating dry mass production losses in water-deficient plants.
population_specificity: Common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) plants grown under field conditions with varying water regimes (80%, 60%, and 40% of soil water retention capacity).
effective_dosage: Si doses of 0, 4, 8, and 12 kg ha⁻¹ via fertigation; potassium replacement dose of 50 kg ha⁻¹ where applicable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) as a killing method on microstructural changes in vanilla beans during curing, compared to traditional scalding.
results_summary: HHP treatment, particularly at 400 MPa, caused more microstructural changes in vanilla beans than scalding, with the core area being most affected. Microscopy techniques and digital image analysis revealed these changes, which peaked at the C16 curing cycle.
population_specificity: Vanilla beans (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inoculation with Bacillus licheniformis M2-7 could reduce fungal contamination and ochratoxin A (OTA) concentration in stored coffee beans.
results_summary: Inoculation with B. licheniformis M2-7 significantly reduced fungal populations (Aspergillus and Penicillium) and decreased OTA concentration from 24.35 ± 1.61 to 5.52 ± 1.69 µg/kg in stored coffee beans. The bacterial strain also inhibited fungal growth rates by 67.8% to 95.5%.
population_specificity: Coffee beans (Coffea arabica L.)

study_goal: The researchers were investigating a case of drug-induced liver injury (DILI) caused by antituberculosis treatment (ATT) and its association with a rare constellation of syndromes.
results_summary: The study reported a case of ATT-induced DILI that did not improve despite modifications in the ATT regime, leading to the discovery of an unreported combination of Wilson Disease, 46 XX gonadal dysgenesis, and MRKH Syndrome. The abstract does not mention any findings related to Beans.
population_specificity: A single case involving a patient with ATT-induced DILI and a rare syndrome constellation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different fermentation treatments (traditional, pre-drying, yeast inoculation, or combined) affect the chemical composition and quality of cocoa beans from the CCN-51 clone.
results_summary: The study found that yeast starter inoculation (YS) and combined pre-drying with yeast inoculation (PD + YS) significantly reduced total polyphenol content, impacting cocoa flavor, while pre-drying (PD) reduced caffeine content. Lactic acid content decreased with yeast inoculation and pre-drying, suggesting these treatments could improve cocoa bean quality.
population_specificity: Cocoa beans of the CCN-51 clone harvested in the Tumaco region (Nariño, Colombia).
effective_dosage: Not specified (fermentation treatments applied for 120 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether 1-methylcyclopropene (1-MCP) could alleviate chilling injury in snap beans during low-temperature storage by enhancing antioxidant defense systems.
results_summary: 1-MCP treatment significantly reduced chilling injury, electrolyte leakage, and malondialdehyde content while increasing antioxidant capacity, phenolic compounds, and the activity of key antioxidant enzymes in snap beans. The treatment also improved retention of quality markers like chlorophyll, ascorbic acid, and total soluble solids.
population_specificity: Snap beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) stored at 4 °C.
effective_dosage: Different volume fractions of 1-MCP (specific concentrations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of soil nitrogen amendments in mitigating ozone stress in two cultivars of Cymopsis tetragonoloba (Beans) and to understand the mechanistic approaches adopted by these cultivars.
results_summary: Nitrogen amendments (particularly the 1.5× recommended dose) effectively enhanced yield in both cultivars (84.8% in S-151 and 76.37% in PUSA-N), with S-151 showing higher yield quantity and PUSA-N showing better yield quality (carbohydrates and nitrogen content). The study also noted increased cellular nitrogen metabolism and RuBisCO accumulation in nitrogen-amended plants.
population_specificity: Two cultivars of Cymopsis tetragonoloba (S-151 and PUSA-N) exposed to ambient ozone stress.
effective_dosage: Recommended (N1), 1.5× recommended (N2), and 2× recommended (N3) nitrogen doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the growth and production parameters of cowpea plants as influenced by potassium fertilization in a specific soil type.
results_summary: The BRS Tumucumaque cultivar showed better growth and production, with optimal results at potassium doses of 90, 135, and 180 kg ha-1, including increased height, stem diameter, grain weight, and pod characteristics.
population_specificity: Cowpea plants (Vigna unguiculata) grown in a greenhouse using soil from the cerrado of Amapá.
effective_dosage: Potassium doses of 45, 90, 135, and 180 kg ha-1 (as potassium chloride).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the supersulfide profiles in protein-rich foods, including beans, to understand their potential health-promoting properties.
results_summary: The study found that beans and their derivatives, particularly natto and bean sprouts, contained higher supersulfide content compared to animal meat, with natto showing the highest proportion (2.15%). These results suggest that supersulfides in beans may contribute to their health benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether induced magnetic field treatment during fermentation or gamma irradiation post-fermentation affects the characteristics of cocoa liquor from Ecuadorian cocoa beans.
results_summary: The study found that both magnetic field treatment (up to 80 mT) and gamma irradiation (up to 3 kGy) influenced cocoa liquor quality, with detectable differences via Raman spectroscopy and variable sensory attributes (floral, fruity, almondy, acid, bitter flavors, astringency, and aroma intensity).
population_specificity: Ecuadorian cocoa beans
effective_dosage: Magnetic field up to 80 mT; gamma irradiation up to 3 kGy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of different postharvest methods (washed and natural) on the antidiabetic activities and phytochemical profiles of GI coffee beans.
results_summary: Naturally processed coffee beans showed significant suppression of DPP4 and α-amylase activities compared to washed beans, with higher chlorogenic acid content. LC-MS/MS analysis revealed distinct phytochemical profiles between the two processing methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on coffee beans, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms behind the lipid-lowering effect of dry beans and how processing techniques influence their ability to modulate lipolysis.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fiber fractions in beans reduce lipolysis by increasing digesta viscosity, with bean flours showing a stronger effect than isolated fiber. Processing methods like hydrothermal treatment weakened this effect, while hydrostatic-pressure treatment enhanced it.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using the INFOGEST static digestion model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of α-amylase from germinated sorghum extract (GSE) on the properties of pre-gelatinized white bean starch, including water holding capacity, freezable water content, and sugar content.
results_summary: The study found that higher annealing temperatures and GSE treatment significantly improved water-holding capacity and sugar content in white bean starch. White bean starch ranked second in freezable water content among the tested starches, and GSE treatment influenced monolayer water content and GAB model parameters.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on starch properties)
effective_dosage: Not specified (annealing at 40, 50, and 60 °C for 30 or 60 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity mechanisms of carbon quantum dots (CQDs) derived from roasted coffee beans and explore methods to reduce their yield.
results_summary: The study found that CQDs from roasted coffee beans increased apoptosis and necroptosis, with toxicity rising with longer roasting times. Pulsed electric field (PEF) treatment effectively reduced CQD yield.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied by apoptosis and toxicity mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the household coverage of iron-biofortified beans (IBBs) in rural areas of the Northern Province of Rwanda.
results_summary: The study found high awareness (79%) of IBBs among surveyed households, but only 10% were currently consuming them. Despite 52% reporting ever consuming biofortified beans, only 40% of bean samples tested were actually biofortified.
population_specificity: Rural households in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous glutathione (GSH) application could mitigate drought-induced damage in common bean plants grown in saline soil conditions.
results_summary: Foliar-applied GSH significantly reduced drought-induced damage in bean plants, improving growth, yield, membrane stability, water status, and photosynthetic capacity. It also enhanced antioxidative machinery and osmolyte content, increasing irrigation use efficiency under water deficit conditions.
population_specificity: Common bean plants (Phaseolus vulgaris) cultivated in saline soil conditions.
study_duration: Two open field growing seasons (2017 and 2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how specific volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from kidney beans affect the selective behavior of western flower thrips (Frankliniella occidentalis) for potential use in integrated pest management (IPM).
results_summary: The study found that certain VOCs (e.g., squalene, dioctyl phthalate, ethyl benzene) attracted F. occidentalis, while others (e.g., 2,6-ditert-butyl-4-methyl phenol) repelled them. Mixtures of these VOCs showed varied effects, with paired combinations attracting thrips but a three-compound mixture having no significant effect.
population_specificity: Western flower thrips (Frankliniella occidentalis).
effective_dosage: 12.7 μL/mL (E, E, E, E)-squalene, 3.2 μL/mL dioctyl phthalate, 82.2 μL/mL ethyl benzene, 10.7 μL/mL and 21.4 μL/mL 2,6-ditert-butyl-4-methyl phenol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different post-treatment fermentation methods (dry, wet, semi-dry, hot air dry) affect the chemical profile and flavor characteristics of medium roasted coffee.
results_summary: The study identified 31 water-soluble and 39 volatile compounds in roasted coffee, showing distinct flavor differentiation based on post-treatment methods. All four treatments produced "specialty coffees" with varied organoleptic characteristics, meeting niche market needs.
population_specificity: Not specified (coffee samples analyzed, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the standardized ileal digestibility (SID) of amino acids in faba beans and three cultivars of field peas in broiler chickens and pigs.
results_summary: The study found that the SID of amino acids in faba beans and field peas was generally higher in broiler chickens than in pigs, with cultivar-specific variations. The 4010 field peas had the lowest SID values in chickens but were comparable to faba beans in pigs.
population_specificity: Male broiler chickens and pigs (barrows).
effective_dosage: Not specified (test ingredients were the sole source of nitrogen in diets).
study_duration: 5 days for broiler chickens; 5-day adaptation followed by 2-day collection for pigs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how fermentation of mung beans by Bacillus subtilis subsp. natto affects their nutritional and functional properties using different reactor designs.
results_summary: Fermentation increased soluble protein and serine levels, attributed to protease activity. SETR fermentation reduced crystallinity and peak temperature compared to static and shaking flask methods, and altered particle size distribution due to mechanical forces and microbial activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on mung beans)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of traditional processing and in vitro gastrointestinal digestion of two bean varieties (Cannellino and Piattellino) on their phytochemical composition and anticancer activity.
results_summary: The study found that the bioaccessible fraction (BF) of cooked beans reduced cell vitality and clonogenicity in colon cancer cell lines (HT29 and HCT116), suggesting anticancer effects through autophagy induction. The extracts appeared selective for colon cancer cells.
population_specificity: Colon cancer cell lines (HT29 and HCT116)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolite profiles of Kopi Luwak coffee brews with washed and unwashed Arabica and Robusta coffees, focusing on caffeine, theophylline, and other compounds.
results_summary: Kopi Luwak coffee showed higher caffeine and theophylline levels compared to washed and unwashed Arabica coffees, with differences in caffeoylquinic isomers. No differences were found in vitamin B3, amines, and phenolic acids between Kopi Luwak and other Arabica coffees. Roasting and post-harvest treatments influenced the concentration of certain acids.
population_specificity: Coffee samples (Arabica and Robusta) of different geographical origins and processing methods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the direct and indirect effects of different Trichoderma strains on insect attacks and the growth of common beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L).
results_summary: The study found that Trichoderma strains varied in their impact on insect survival and bean germination, with Tb41 causing the lowest insect survival rate and Δtri23 showing the highest germination capacity and plant dry weight.
population_specificity: Common beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L) and the insect pest Acanthoscelides obtectus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aerobic and anaerobic moist incubation on nonvolatile components in cocoa beans, relative to traditional fermentation and unfermented cocoa.
results_summary: Aerobically incubated cocoa showed lower phenolic compounds than unfermented or anaerobically incubated cocoa, while methylxanthine levels remained unchanged. Reducing sugars increased more than 2-fold after incubation, and free amino acids were highest after anaerobic incubation.
population_specificity: Cocoa beans (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (moist incubation involved rehydration with lactic acid solution containing ethanol, followed by 72 h incubation at 45 °C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an electronic nose (E-nose) could discriminate between coffee beans roasted at different thermal treatment intensities based on their aromatic compounds.
results_summary: The study found that the E-nose effectively discriminated roasted coffee beans subjected to different thermal treatments, with specific volatile organic compounds (VOCs) linked to positive and negative aromas. The PLS model quantified these aromas with high accuracy (RCV2 = 0.92).
population_specificity: Coffee beans (no human subjects involved).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (thermal treatment intensities varied but exact dosages not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize an HPLC-UV method for analyzing L-Dopa in broad beans and determine the best storage conditions to preserve L-Dopa content.
results_summary: The study developed a validated HPLC-UV method for reliable L-Dopa analysis, identifying sun-drying as the best storage treatment and optimal extraction conditions (0.1 M HCl). The method addressed stability and separation challenges for L-Dopa determination.
population_specificity: Broad beans (Vicia faba L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant activity of selenium, garlic husk, and lemon peel-treated faba beans and their protective/therapeutic effects in a rat model of ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Treated faba beans showed increased selenium, nitrogen, potassium, protein, phenolics, and flavonoids, enhancing antioxidant capacity. Consumption reduced oxidative stress and improved antioxidant defenses in colitis-induced rats.
population_specificity: Female rats (n=54, divided into 9 groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of auricular point pressing beans combined with continuous intervention on β2-microglobulin levels, clinical efficacy, and prognosis in elderly maintenance hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that auricular acupuncture combined with continuous intervention improved clinical therapy effects, inflammatory and renal function indexes, reduced readmission rates, and enhanced prognosis quality of life in elderly MHD patients.
population_specificity: Elderly maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) sufferers (n=110, aged unspecified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify drought- and low phosphorus-tolerant common bean genotypes suitable for tropical climates, focusing on their reproductive development and yield performance under stress conditions.
results_summary: The study found that SEF-line bean genotypes demonstrated heat and drought tolerance, achieving physiological maturity, while other genotypes failed to pod under high temperatures. Optimal phosphorus and water conditions significantly improved root growth compared to stressed conditions.
population_specificity: Forty common bean accessions of multiple genetic backgrounds, evaluated under screen-house conditions in Ghana.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between the novel fungal species Parametarhizium hingganense and mung beans (Vigna radiata), focusing on growth promotion and defense response priming.
results_summary: The study found that symbiosis with P. hingganense promoted mung bean growth, enhanced phosphorus content, elevated jasmonic acid (JA) and gibberellin (GA1) levels, and increased total phenolic and flavonoid content. Additionally, it alleviated damping off caused by Rhizoctonia solani in mycorrhizal plants.
population_specificity: Mung beans (Vigna radiata)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how roasting conditions affect the concentration of physiologically active compounds in coffee beans, comparing decaffeinated and non-decaffeinated beans.
results_summary: Decaffeination reduced caffeine and slightly reduced trigonelline, while chlorogenic acids remained largely unchanged. Roasting at high temperatures degraded most compounds except caffeine, but decaffeinated beans required less thermal history for complete roasting, preserving more chlorogenic acid.
population_specificity: Coffee beans (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the presence of amyloid-like protein aggregates in soya beans due to high-temperature processing.
results_summary: The study found that isolated protein aggregates from hydrated soya beans displayed typical amyloid characteristics, including Congo red shift, high ThT and ANS binding, and fibrillar morphology. These aggregates were proteolytically stable, raising concerns about their implications for human nutrition and health.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on soya bean proteins)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat treatment (toasting) and particle size alterations (grinding; rolling) of fava beans on nutrient utilization, ruminal fermentation, and metabolizable protein supply in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that neither toasting nor rolling fava beans significantly affected metabolizable protein supply. Diets high in corn silage improved crude protein and starch digestibility but reduced fiber digestibility compared to grass-clover silage. Rolling fava beans reduced starch and amino acid digestibility compared to grinding.
population_specificity: Six Danish Holstein dairy cows fitted with ruminal, duodenal, and ileal cannulas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the thermal transitions and denaturation of bean proteins during cooking and their impact on protein digestibility.
results_summary: The study found that chickpea proteins were more thermally stable than lentil and bean proteins, and protein denaturation was irreversible, suggesting coupled unfolding and aggregation. The modeling allowed for calculating protein transition degrees under various temperature and moisture conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (protein-enriched samples from dehulled seeds).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (thermal treatment up to 160 °C with varying water content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of lupines and faba beans as ingredients for vegan, functional, and sustainable beverages, focusing on improving their sensory and nutritional attributes through germination, heat treatment, enzymatic treatment, and lactic acid fermentation.
results_summary: The study found that the "beany" aroma is a major off-flavor in legume-based beverages, but sensory and nutritional improvements are possible through substrate modulation and fermentation. Combining these processes could enhance flavor and protein content, making legumes more viable for beverage applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general application for beverage industry)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar spraying of uniconazole could mitigate chilling stress in mung beans at the flowering stage by enhancing antioxidant capacity and protecting photosynthetic machinery.
results_summary: Uniconazole significantly improved chilling stress tolerance in mung beans by boosting antioxidant enzyme activity, photosynthetic efficiency, and yield-related traits, resulting in a 53.47% increase in grain weight per plant compared to chilling-treated plants.
population_specificity: Mung beans at the flowering stage under chilling stress (15°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cooking and steaming affect the nutritional metabolic components of black beans.
results_summary: Heat processing significantly altered metabolic components in black beans, with steaming better retaining nutrients compared to cooking. Cooking reduced amino acids, lipids, polyphenols, sugars, and nucleosides, while steaming reduced amino acids and lipids but increased polyphenols, sugars, and nucleosides.
population_specificity: Black beans (no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe cases of intoxication from castor beans and jequirity beans, focusing on the toxins ricin and abrin, their mechanisms, and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Both patients experienced mild clinical courses despite ingestion of toxic beans; severity depended on chewing and toxin amount. No antidote exists, and treatment involves anti-absorptive measures and supportive care.
population_specificity: Two patients (one ingested castor beans, the other jequirity beans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hot water treatment against Frankliniella occidentalis eggs on French beans and its impact on postharvest quality parameters.
results_summary: The study found that hot water treatment at 45°C for 8.01 minutes achieved a 99.9968% control level of F. occidentalis eggs with no survivors in confirmatory tests. The treatment had no significant effect on the quality parameters of French beans.
population_specificity: French beans infested with Frankliniella occidentalis eggs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of feeding faba beans (FB) on the growth performance and cost efficiency of lambs compared to a conventional diet.
results_summary: Lambs fed the FB200 diet showed higher nutrient intake, improved digestibility of certain nutrients, increased nitrogen retention, higher average daily gain, and reduced cost of gain compared to the control diet, though final body weight did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Male lambs (n=24)
study_duration: 70 days (7 days acclimatization, 63 days data collection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sulfur and amino acids (serine and glutamine) in mitigating lead toxicity stress on green bean plants and improving yield and safety for human consumption.
results_summary: The study found that foliar application of sulfur, serine, and glutamine reduced lead toxicity effects, decreased hydrogen peroxide and grain protein, increased glutathione activity, and reduced lead accumulation in edible pods. However, lead exposure negatively impacted leaf area, dry weight, stem diameter, height, pod yield, and photosynthetic pigments.
population_specificity: Green bean Sunray cultivar plants
effective_dosage: Lead acetate (0.0 and 1 mmol), liquid sulfur (0.0 and 2 per thousand), serine (200 mg/L), glutamine (200 mg/L), and co-application of serine and glutamine (200 mg/L each)
study_duration: Applied at pre-flowering stage (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of folic acid (FA) foliar application on snap bean seedlings' growth and stress tolerance under non-saline and salinity stress conditions.
results_summary: FA treatment significantly improved growth parameters, chlorophyll content, antioxidant enzyme activities, and stress-related gene expression under salinity stress, while reducing oxidative damage and sodium accumulation. The 0.2 mM FA dose was more effective than 0.1 mM.
population_specificity: Snap bean seedlings (Phaseolus vulgaris)
effective_dosage: 0.1 mM and 0.2 mM FA as foliar application

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the storage stability of quick-cooking dehydrated beans using the glass transition concept and assess the impact of storage temperatures on their rehydration and quality characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that higher storage temperatures and longer durations reduced rehydration rate constants and ability, with increased hardness. While color remained stable, new volatiles formed at elevated temperatures (28-42°C). Dehydrated beans with 10% moisture stored below 28°C maintained quality in a glassy state.
population_specificity: Quick-cooking dehydrated beans (Phaseolus vulgaris L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplements, particularly when combined with calcium, reduce the incidence of falls and fractures in elderly populations.
results_summary: Vitamin D with calcium significantly reduced fall incidence (RR = 0.881) and fracture rates (RR = 0.859), while vitamin D alone did not show significant benefits for fracture reduction.
population_specificity: Elderly women under 80 years of age.
